item.title: Where Are All The Tourists From 3025?
item.description: arXiv:2508.09157v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: This paper examines the distinct lack of clear examples of time-travellers and proposes an explanation for their absence without assuming technical barriers to constructing time machines. Instead, it develops and then analyses a model of the consequences of time-travellers; finding that time travel is self-suppressing.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jackson

item.title: Riemann Zero Condition Off the Critical Line: A Matrix Formulation
item.description: arXiv:2411.17701v3 Announce Type: replace Abstract: This work introduces a finite-size symmetric matrix approach to describe the condition for zeros of the Riemann zeta function, applicable to complex numbers whose real part is not one-half. For a given complex number and a cutoff size, a special matrix is defined with entries based on the product of indices raised to a power related to the complex number. The total sum of all matrix entries splits naturally into two parts: one involving only diagonal elements and the other involving off-diagonal elements. When the real part of the complex number is greater than one, the diagonal part approaches the value of the zeta function, and the off-diagonal part remains finite, leading to an exact cancellation if the zeta function equals zero. When the real part is greater than two, both sums converge absolutely as the cutoff increases. This approach can be extended beyond the real part greater than one-half by analytic continuation, meaning the cancellation condition holds for all nontrivial zeros off the critical line. On the critical line itself, both parts diverge logarithmically but can be regularized in a consistent way, resulting in an identity equivalent to the famous Riemann Hypothesis.
item.dc:creator: Chee Kian Yap
